docs.lead_paragraph: The state attorney general has sued 16 restaurant owners for failing to post warnings that tuna, shark and swordfish can contain unhealthful levels of mercury, which can pose a risk to fetuses. The suits said the restaurants violated a state law requiring businesses to notify consumers of potential toxic exposure. They follow similar lawsuits that prompted major supermarket chains to post warnings. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Lawsuit About Mercury Warnings

docs.abstract: California sues 16 restaurant owners for failing to post warnings about mercury levels in shark, tuna and swordfish, which can pose danger to fetuses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Marion Jones is pregnant and will not compete this year in any events, including the world championships in Paris, where she would be the defending 200-meter champion. But she promises to be ready for the Athens Olympics next year.
docs.abstract: Marion Jones will not compete in any track and field events this year to give birth to baby (S)
docs.snippet: Marion Jones is pregnant and will not compete this year in any events, including the world championships in Paris, where she would be the defending 200-meter champion. But she promises to be ready for the Athens Olympics next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: A 65-year-old Orissa woman gave birth to her first child, a six-and-a-half-pound boy. The woman, Satyabhama Mahapatra, had the baby by Caesarean section on Tuesday at a hospital in eastern India, the Times of India reported. She had been implanted with an embryo from her niece and had been hospitalized for the last three months and given hormones. Hospital officials had discouraged the woman and her husband, a retired school teacher, from having a baby at her age. But the couple refused to forgo ''this last chance,'' the newspaper said. According to the Guinness Book of Records, a 63-year-old woman gave birth to a boy in 1994.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: India: Planning For Retirement

docs.abstract: Satyabhama Mahapatra, who is 65, gives birth to first child--a six-and-a-half-pound boy--in Orissa, India; embryo was donated by niece; Satyabhama Mahapatra was given hormones and was hospitalized for past three months; is oldest woman on record to give birth (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 19 babies in the neonatal intensive care unit at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn were typical of the infants in similar hospitals elsewhere. Eighteen were born weeks or months before term, defined as 37 or more weeks after the mother's last menstrual period.

headline.main: Premature Births Rise Sharply, Confounding Obstetricians

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Science Times article focuses on various aspects of rising rate of premature births in US, which have grown 27% since 1981 to more than 1,300 preterm births daily; notes that emphasis of research by National Institute of Child Health and Human Development is in finding markers to identify women likely to deliver preterm before actual labor begins; holds that, even when identified early treatments have not been fully developed to keep labor at bay; notes that tocolytic treatments can delay labor 24 to 48 hours giving physicians time to administer drugs to speed fetal lung maturation and reduce risk of brain hemorrhage; says that fetal membrane infection, multiple pregnancy, separation of placenta and stress on mother or baby are four factors that have been identified as potential tiggers of premature labor; photos (L)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: We hear about the miracles: the babies born weighing two pounds or less who grow up to play sports and graduate from high school, even college. But rarely do people hear the very sad stories of the thousands of tiny babies born months before their time who do not do nearly as well, who spend three months in the hospital, sometimes suffering crisis after crisis and finally emerging with lifelong sensory, mental or physical disabilities.

headline.main: Experts Strive to Make More Pregnancies Full Term

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column gives overview of factors that influence woman's ability to carry baby to full term and details what symptoms of early labor pregnant women should look for to avoid complications; factors such as maternal age, demographic background, prenatal care, body weight, pre-existing health conditions, history of premature birth and early uterine contractions can all increase risk of delivering premature baby; possible drug therapies and causes of infant mortality are charted; graph (M)
